questionText: What is the correct file extension for Java source code files?
explanation: Java source code files use the .java extension. After compilation, they become .class files (bytecode). .jar files are Java archives, and .jdk refers to the Java Development Kit.

questionText: Which command is used to compile a Java program and create bytecode?
explanation: The 'javac' (Java Compiler) command compiles .java source files into .class bytecode files. Example: javac HelloWorld.java creates HelloWorld.class

questionText: Which command is used to run a compiled Java program?
explanation: The 'java' command runs compiled Java bytecode. Example: java HelloWorld (note: no .class extension). The JVM (Java Virtual Machine) executes the bytecode.

questionText: For public classes in Java, what is the relationship between the class name and the file name?
options: File name must match the public class name exactly (case-sensitive)
File name should be lowercase version of class name
Only the first letter must match
explanation: A public class MUST be in a file with the exact same name (case-sensitive). If your class is 'public class HelloWorld', the file must be 'HelloWorld.java'. Non-public classes can have different names.

questionText: What symbol must end every statement in Java?
explanation: Every Java statement must end with a semicolon (;). This tells the compiler where one statement ends and another begins. Forgetting it causes compilation errors.

questionText: What method is used to print output with a new line automatically added at the end in Java?
explanation: System.out.println() prints text and adds a newline at the end, moving the cursor to the next line. 'println' stands for 'print line'.

questionText: What is the difference between print() and println() in Java?
options: No difference, they work the same
println() adds a new line (line break) after printing
explanation: print() displays output without a newline, keeping the cursor on the same line. println() adds a newline after output, moving to the next line. Both can print any data type.

questionText: Which escape sequence represents a new line (line break) in Java?
explanation: \n creates a new line. Example: System.out.print("Hello\nWorld"); prints Hello on one line and World on the next. \t is tab, \r is carriage return, \b is backspace.

questionText: Which escape sequence represents a tab character in Java?
explanation: \t inserts a tab character (typically 4-8 spaces of indentation). Example: System.out.println("Name:\tJohn"); creates space between Name: and John.

questionText: How do you write a single-line comment in Java?
explanation: Java uses // for single-line comments. Everything after // on that line is ignored by the compiler. # is used in Python, <!-- --> in HTML, and ' in Visual Basic.

questionText: What is the correct syntax for a multi-line comment in Java?
explanation: Multi-line comments in Java use /* to start and */ to end. Everything between is ignored by the compiler. Example: /* This is a multi-line comment spanning several lines */

questionText: What is the correct capitalization for System.out.println() in Java?
explanation: Java is case-sensitive. The correct syntax is System.out.println() with capital 'S', lowercase 'out', and lowercase 'println'. Any variation will cause a compilation error.

questionText: What characters are used to define code blocks (like method bodies and class bodies) in Java?
explanation: Curly braces { } define code blocks in Java. They mark the beginning and end of classes, methods, loops, and conditionals. Proper brace matching is essential.

questionText: Which method must every standalone Java application have as its entry point?
explanation: The main() method is the entry point where program execution begins. The JVM looks for this method to start running your program. Without it, the program won't run.

questionText: What is the correct signature (declaration) for the main method in Java?
explanation: The main method must be: public (accessible), static (can run without creating an object), void (returns nothing), and accept String[] args (command-line arguments array).

questionText: If your public class is named 'HelloWorld', what must your Java file be named?
explanation: The filename must exactly match the public class name, including capitalization: HelloWorld.java. Java is case-sensitive, so any variation will cause a compilation error.

questionText: How do you include a single backslash character (\) in a Java string literal?
explanation: In Java code, write \\ (two backslashes) to represent one backslash in the actual string. The first backslash escapes the second. Example: String path = "C:\\Users\\";

questionText: How do you include double quotes (") inside a string literal in Java?
explanation: Use \" to include double quotes in a string. Example: System.out.println("He said \"Hello\""); outputs: He said "Hello". The backslash escapes the quote.

questionText: What type of file is created after successfully compiling a Java program?
explanation: The Java compiler (javac) creates .class files containing bytecode. This bytecode runs on any platform with a JVM, making Java platform-independent. .jar files are archives of multiple .class files.

questionText: What happens if you forget a semicolon at the end of a statement in Java?
options: A compilation error occurs and the program won't compile
A warning appears but the program still runs
Only a runtime error occurs when you run the program
explanation: Missing semicolons cause compilation errors. The compiler cannot translate the code to bytecode and displays an error message like 'error: ';' expected'. The program won't run until fixed.
